messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] mei help
messages.msgSnippet: The Bu kanji tends to relate to military things.  The second appears 2nd in compounds meaning canal, inlet, etc.  Perhaps the location is on some small
messages.messageBody:
The Bu kanji tends to relate to military things. The second appears 2nd in compounds meaning canal, inlet, etc. Perhaps the location is on some small waterway in Edo, or is a pun we don't understand, or is some other real location that isn't prominent in the first line references. Any help?

Jim



Jim, I had this response on my message board, basically Afu told me the same thing.

Top Kanji "Bu",second Kanji "Ko"="E/Ye". That is "Bu" is Bu-shu/Musashi no kuni,"Ko" is Edo(Tokyo). Mei is Kunimasa.

Cheers

Rich
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, November 15, 2003 11:48 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] mei help


Rich,
You're seeing the kanji correctly, but I don't recognize the place name. I've checked a few books and come up with nothing. Does anyone have a comprehensive Japanese reference book on place names?

Jim



hi all, I was looking at this mei and got stuck on the province, looks like the first half of Bushu and the last half of Omi, I cant find a reference for this, Is it time for new glasses ?????

any help please ?????

http://www.pixhost.com/pixo/onstage/17a.jpg

Rich

messages.msgSnippet: ... Actually, I think it is near, at least somewhat near Disneyland :-) Or was that Fantasy Island I was thinking of???? :-)

wrote:
> Hi Rich, A town known unto only itself, interesting :-)
>

Actually, I think it is near, at least somewhat near Disneyland :-)
Or was that Fantasy Island I was thinking of???? :-)

> Rich S

Rich

Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: mei help

I can see. Maybe Bushomi ??? :-)

Rich S
